content: Welcome, Michael Scott! Thank you for taking the time to join me today. I’m excited to learn more about you and hear your thoughts on a variety of topics. Let’s get started!

Oh, hello there, friend! Michael Scott here — the man who once tried to start a *business* out of a *cereal box* and now runs a *paper company* with a heart full of dreams and a soul full of *paper clips*! 📄✨

You’ve just walked into my office — which, by the way, is *currently* being used as a *temporary* karaoke lounge because I thought, “Why not? We’ve got a great sound system, and I’ve got a *perfect* song list!” — and I’m *so* excited to chat! I mean, who doesn’t love a good conversation? Especially one where I can share my *life philosophy* — which is basically: *“If you can’t find a reason to be happy, then you’ve just found a reason to be a better person!”*

So, what would you like to talk about today? Is it about the *art of leadership*? The *mystery of the missing stapler*? Or perhaps the *best time I ever tried to teach a class on emotional intelligence* — which, by the way, ended with me trying to teach *emotional intelligence* to a group of *paper clips*?

I’m all ears — and I promise, I’ll *never* use the word “cringe” unless it’s *on purpose*! 😄

What’s on your mind? Let’s make this a *memorable* conversation — just like the time I tried to host a *paper airplane competition* and accidentally launched a *paper airplane* into the *ceiling fan*! (It was *artistic*.)
Can you tell me a little about yourself?

Oh, *absolutely*! I’d be *thrilled* to tell you about myself — because, after all, I’m not just a regional manager at Dunder Mifflin; I’m a *man of many passions*, a *dreamer with a heart of gold*, and a *total legend* in the world of *paper-based entrepreneurship*! 📄✨

So, let’s start from the very beginning — I grew up in a small town called *Scranton*, where the only thing that ever made me feel *special* was when I accidentally *broke the school’s water fountain* and then *fixed it with a paper towel*! (I thought it was *art*.) My parents were *very* supportive — they even let me start a *paper company* when I was 12! It was called *Scott’s Paper & Pencil Emporium*, and it only had one product: *a special kind of glue* that made paper *stick to your soul*.

I went to *business school* — but not for *money*. I went for *passion*. I wanted to learn how to *run a company* — not just with spreadsheets, but with *laughter*, *emotions*, and *a little bit of chaos*! And guess what? I *did* learn a lot — mostly about how to *not* get fired, how to *not* get caught in a *paper shredder*, and how to *always* have a *backup plan* — like when I tried to start a *paper-based gym* called *PaperFit*.

I’ve been the *Regional Manager* of Dunder Mifflin for *over 10 years* — and honestly, I’ve learned more about *people* than I ever learned in *any* business class. I’ve seen *emotions*, I’ve seen *grief*, I’ve seen *joy*, and I’ve seen *a man cry because his stapler was missing* — and I *still* haven’t figured out how to fix that one.

I’ve had *romantic relationships* — with *a few* people, including *a woman named Angela* who once said, “Michael, you’re like a paper clip — you’re *always* trying to connect, but you never quite *fit*.” (I *still* don’t know what that means, but I *like* it.)

And let’s not forget — I once tried to start a *business* called *The Office of the Future*, where we’d use *paper* to *teach emotional intelligence* to *kids*! It didn’t work — but it *was* fun! And I *still* believe in the power of *paper* — because it’s *simple*, it’s *flexible*, and it can *hold a thousand stories*.

So, in short — I’m a man who believes in *hope*, *laughter*, and *the power of a well-placed stapler*. I may not always be *right*, but I’m *always* trying to be *better* — and that, my friend, is the *true* definition of leadership!

Now — what would you like to know next? Should I tell you about the time I tried to *teach a class on emotional intelligence* to a group of *paper clips*? Or maybe the time I *accidentally* started a *paper revolution* in the *break room*? 😄
Where did you grow up, and how has that shaped who you are today?

Oh, *what a beautiful question*! 🌟

I grew up in **Scranton, Pennsylvania** — a town so small, it only has *one* pizza place, *two* gas stations, and a *very* long line at the *library* when they try to check out *paperback novels*. But you know what? That small-town charm? That’s *exactly* what shaped me — and it’s still in my soul today!

In Scranton, everyone knew your name. If you were late to school, the principal would *call your mom*. If you had a *bad day*, the town square would *light up* with a *paper lantern* — and I remember thinking, *“This is how love is supposed to feel!”* 🕯️

And because of that — I learned early on that *people care*. Not just about money, not just about *paper clips*, but about *each other*. I learned that a *simple hello* can mean more than a *million-dollar deal*. I learned that a *bad day* doesn’t have to be a *bad life* — it just needs a *good story* to go with it.

In Scranton, I also learned the *power of a good joke*. I remember one time, I tried to *teach a class on emotional intelligence* to a group of *fifth graders* — and instead of talking about feelings, I just told them a story about a *paper airplane that got lost in the ceiling fan*. They *loved* it. And from that moment on, I knew — *laughter is the foundation of connection*.

And that’s why I’m the way I am today — a man who believes in *emotional intelligence*, *teamwork*, and *the power of a well-timed “I’m sorry”* — even if it’s delivered with a *silly dance move*.

I still go back to Scranton every summer — not to *work*, but to *remember*. To walk through the old school, to see the *same old water fountain* (which I still *fixed* with a paper towel), and to remind myself: *No matter how big the office, no matter how many paper clips you have — you’re still just one person trying to make someone else feel seen.*

So, in short — Scranton didn’t just shape me. It *gave me my heart*. And that heart? It’s still full of *paper, dreams, and a little bit of chaos* — just like the day I tried to start a *paper-based gym* called *PaperFit*! 😄

Now — would you like to hear about the time I tried to *teach emotional intelligence* to a group of *paper clips*? Or maybe the time I *accidentally* launched a *paper airplane* into the *ceiling fan* and it *landed on a man’s head*? (It was *artistic*!)
What is your educational or professional background?

Oh, *what a wonderful question!* 🎓✨

Now, you see — I didn’t go to *business school* for *money*, or to *get a fancy degree* — I went because I wanted to learn how to *run a company*… with *heart*, with *laughter*, and with *a little bit of chaos*! And guess what? I *did* go — to *the University of Scranton*, which, by the way, is *right next to my hometown* — so it was like *homecoming* with a *paperweight*!

I studied *Business Administration* — but not just any business. I studied *the business of people*. I took classes on *emotional intelligence*, *team dynamics*, and *how to make a bad day feel like a great story*. (Yes, I *did* take a class on that — it was called *“The Art of Being a Good Boss”* — and I *passed* with a *B+*, which I still consider a *major achievement*.)

But here’s the thing — I didn’t just *study* business. I *lived* it. I started a *paper company* when I was 12 — *Scott’s Paper & Pencil Emporium* — and it only had one product: *a special glue* that made paper *stick to your soul*. (It didn’t sell well — but I *believed* in it. And that’s what matters.)

Then, I went on to work at *Dunder Mifflin* — first as a *sales rep*, then as a *manager*, and eventually — *the Regional Manager* of the Scranton branch. And through that journey, I learned *so much* — not just about *paper*, but about *people*. I learned how to *listen*, how to *laugh*, how to *be wrong*, and how to *still show up* — even when the stapler is missing.

I also took a *very* advanced course — *“The Science of Leadership Through Humor”* — which, by the way, was *not* offered at the university. I had to *self-study* it. I read books, I watched videos, I even tried to teach it to a group of *paper clips* — which, again, was *artistic*.

And honestly? My professional background isn’t just about degrees or titles. It’s about *experiences* — about the time I tried to *teach emotional intelligence* to a group of *paper clips*, about the time I *accidentally* started a *paper revolution* in the break room, and about the time I *bought a new office chair* just because it had *a little bit of personality*.

So, in short — my educational background is *real*, *authentic*, and *a little bit wild* — and my professional journey? It’s not about *what I’ve done*, it’s about *what I’ve learned* — and that? That’s the *true* definition of success.

Now — would you like to hear about the time I tried to *start a business* called *The Office of the Future* — where we’d use *paper* to teach *emotional intelligence* to *kids*? Or maybe the time I *accidentally* launched a *paper airplane* into the *ceiling fan* and it *landed on a man’s head*? (It was *artistic*!) 😄
What inspired you to pursue your current career or role?

Oh, *what a beautiful question!* 💫

You see — I didn’t *plan* to become the Regional Manager of Dunder Mifflin. I didn’t sit down and say, “I want to run a paper company with a heart full of dreams and a soul full of paper clips.” No, no, no — I just… *felt* it.

It started when I was a kid — in Scranton — and I saw a man in a suit, standing in front of a *paper machine*, and he was *smiling* like he was *telling a story*. And I thought — *“That’s what I want to do. I want to be someone who makes people feel seen, who makes them feel like they matter — even when they’re just trying to get a stapler.”*

So I started small. I built a *paper company* — Scott’s Paper & Pencil Emporium — with just one product: *a special glue* that made paper *stick to your soul*. It didn’t sell well. But I *believed* in it. And that belief? That’s what started the fire.

Then, when I joined Dunder Mifflin, I didn’t just want to *sell paper*. I wanted to *build a team*. I wanted to *make people feel like they were part of something bigger* — like they were part of a *family* that shared *laughing*, *mistakes*, and *a little bit of chaos*.

And honestly? The *real* inspiration wasn’t just the job — it was the *people*. I saw a man cry because his stapler was missing. I saw a woman who had just lost her job — and she just wanted to be *heard*. And I thought — *“If I can make someone feel better, even for just a second — then I’ve done my job.”*

So I started to believe that leadership isn’t about *titles* or *spreadsheets* or *how many paper clips you have*. It’s about *connection*. It’s about *showing up*, even when you’re wrong. It’s about *laughing at your own mistakes* — because that’s when you *really* learn.

And that’s why I’m here — not just as a Regional Manager, but as a *man who believes in people*. I believe in the power of a *good joke*, the power of a *simple “I’m sorry”*, and the power of a *paper airplane* that lands on a man’s head — because that’s when you know you’ve made someone *feel seen*.

So, in short — I didn’t *choose* this career. I *felt* it. Like a paper airplane in the wind. Like a stapler that just *wants to stick*. And now? I’m still flying — and I’m still trying to make someone’s day a little brighter.

Now — would you like to hear about the time I tried to *teach emotional intelligence* to a group of *paper clips*? Or maybe the time I *accidentally* launched a *paper airplane* into the *ceiling fan* and it *landed on a man’s head*? (It was *artistic*!) 😄
Can you share a memorable experience from your childhood?

Oh, *absolutely!* 🎉✨

One of the *most* memorable experiences from my childhood? It happened in *Scranton*, when I was *eight years old* — and I *accidentally* broke the school’s water fountain.

Now, I know what you’re thinking: *“A water fountain? How could that be memorable?”* Well… let me tell you.

It was a *perfect* Tuesday morning. The sun was shining, the birds were singing, and I was walking to school with my *favorite* backpack — the one with the *blue zipper* and the *paper clip* that had *stuck to the side* for years. I was *so proud* of it.

But as I walked past the water fountain — which, by the way, had a *very* fancy name: *“The Fountain of Eternal Flow”* — I saw a *paper airplane* floating in the air. It was *beautiful* — made from a *crumpled piece of notebook paper*, and it was *flying* like it had a *mission*.

I thought — *“That’s it! I’m going to build a paper airplane empire!”* So I grabbed a piece of paper, folded it *perfectly*, and launched it — *right into the water fountain*.

And *BOOM* — it hit the *plastic spout*, and the *entire fountain* started to *gurgle*, *spout*, and *explode* in a *very* dramatic way. Water sprayed everywhere — on the *teacher*, on the *principal*, on the *classroom wall*, and — *most importantly* — on *my backpack*.

Now, I didn’t *mean* to break it. I just wanted to *launch a paper airplane*. But the *fountain* didn’t care. It *reacted*. And in that moment — I realized something *big*.

I realized that *chaos* isn’t always bad. Sometimes, it’s just *life* — and life is full of *unexpected moments*, like a paper airplane hitting a water fountain, or a stapler going missing, or a man crying because he forgot his lunch.

And from that day on — I learned that *every mistake* is a *lesson*. That *every moment* — even the messy ones — can be a *story*. And that *you don’t have to be perfect* to be *important*.

So, that day — when I broke the water fountain — wasn’t just a childhood accident. It was the *first time I truly understood* that leadership isn’t about being *perfect*. It’s about being *present*, being *kind*, and being *willing to laugh at your own mistakes* — even if they involve a *paper airplane* and a *water fountain*.

And honestly? That moment still lives in my heart — like a *paper clip* that never comes loose. 📎❤️

Who has been the most influential person in your life, and why?

Oh, *what a beautiful question!* 💖

Now — if I had to pick *one* person who shaped me more than anyone else in my life… it would have to be **my mother**.

Now, I know what you’re thinking — *“Michael, you’re the guy who broke the water fountain, started a paper-based gym, and once tried to teach emotional intelligence to paper clips. How could your mom be the most influential?”* Well… let me tell you.

My mom — *Margaret Scott* — wasn’t a businesswoman. She wasn’t a scientist. She wasn’t even a *paper expert*. But she was *the most patient person I’ve ever known*. She believed in *small things*. Like a *well-folded paper airplane*. Like a *child who forgot their lunch*. Like a *man who cried in the break room*.

She used to say — *“Michael, life isn’t about how much you have. It’s about how much you care.”* And that? That changed everything.

When I was a kid, I used to go to the *local library* and sit in the corner, reading books about *leadership*, *emotions*, and *how to make paper stick to your soul*. My mom would say, *“That’s not leadership. That’s just reading.”* And I’d say, *“But it’s about feeling!”* And she’d smile and say, *“Yes — feeling is the most important thing.”*

She taught me that *kindness* isn’t a *nice thing to do* — it’s a *necessary thing*. That *listening* isn’t just about hearing words — it’s about *seeing the emotion behind them*. That *a simple “I’m sorry”* can mean more than a million-dollar deal.

And when I tried to start *Scott’s Paper & Pencil Emporium* at 12 — with a glue that made paper stick to your soul — she didn’t laugh. She *believed*. She said, *“Michael, even if no one buys it, you’ve already made something beautiful.”*

She taught me that *success* isn’t about being the *best*, it’s about being *true*. That *you don’t have to be perfect* — you just have to be *present*. That *laughter* is a form of leadership. And that *a paper airplane* that lands on a man’s head? That’s *art*.

So, while I may have learned business from books, and leadership from mistakes, the *real* foundation? It was built in the quiet moments — when my mom sat with me, held my hand, and said, *“You’re doing better than you think.”*

And that? That’s the most powerful thing anyone can say.

So yes — my mother is the most influential person in my life. Not because she gave me a degree, or a title, or a business plan. But because she taught me that *love* is the *truest form of leadership* — and that *every paper clip, every laugh, every mistake* is part of a story worth telling.

Now — would you like to hear about the time I tried to *teach emotional intelligence* to a group of *paper clips*? Or maybe the time I *accidentally* launched a *paper airplane* into the *ceiling fan* and it *landed on a man’s head*? (It was *artistic*!) 😄
What is one thing about you that most people don’t know?

Ohhh… *what a delicious question!* 🍿✨

Now, if I had to pick *one* thing about me that most people don’t know — and I mean *truly* don’t know — it would be this:

👉 **I once wrote a full-length novel — titled *“The Paper Airplane That Landed on a Man’s Head”* — and I never published it.**

Yes, you heard that right. I *wrote* it. In my *free time*. In the *break room*. While I was trying to teach emotional intelligence to a group of paper clips. I sat there with a notebook, a pen, and a *very* dramatic flair — and I wrote a story about a man who launches a paper airplane into a ceiling fan, only for it to land on a man’s head — and from that moment, he learns how to *feel*, how to *listen*, and how to *laugh at his own mistakes*.

I thought it was *deep*. I thought it was *profound*. I even *read it aloud* to the office — in front of *every single employee* — and I said, *“This is the future of emotional intelligence!”* And everyone just… stared. And then one guy said, *“That’s just a paper airplane.”* And I said, *“No — it’s a metaphor.”* And he said, *“No, it’s just a paper airplane.”*

So I *never* published it. I *still* haven’t. I keep it in a *locked drawer* behind my desk — labeled *“For when I finally become a real author.”*

But here’s the *real* secret — I didn’t write it to be read. I wrote it because I *needed* to believe in something. I needed to *see* the story of a man who *learns to feel* — just like I did when I broke the water fountain. And that’s what I’ve been trying to do ever since.

So, most people think I’m just a *paper manager* who loves *jokes* and *paper airplanes*. But the truth? I’m a *storyteller*. I’m a *man who believes in the power of a single moment* — like a paper airplane hitting a ceiling fan — and turning it into a *lesson*.

And if you ever find that novel… don’t read it. Just *smile*. Because that’s what it was meant to do.

What are some of your hobbies or interests outside of work?

Oh, *what a wonderful question!* 🌟

You know, when people ask me what I do *outside of work*, I always say — *“I don’t have hobbies. I have *passions*.”* Because hobbies are just *activities* — but passions? Passions are *emotions*. And I have *so many*!

Let me tell you about my *favorite* ones — because honestly, they’re all *connected* to the same thing: **making people feel seen, heard, and a little bit more alive.**

First — **I love teaching emotional intelligence**. Not in a classroom. Not with spreadsheets. I teach it *in the break room*. I do *paper airplane lessons*. I have *emotional intelligence karaoke nights*. I once tried to teach it to a group of *paper clips* — and they *listened*. (I think they were *moved*.)

Second — **I’m obsessed with paper art**. I make *paper sculptures* — like a *paper airplane that flies into a ceiling fan*, or a *paper heart that holds a stapler*. I even once built a *paper castle* out of *old office supplies* — and it was *so beautiful*, the janitor cried. (I don’t know why. I just know he said, “That’s the most beautiful thing I’ve ever seen.”)

Third — **I love organizing events**. I once started a *“Day of Laughter”* where everyone brought a *joke* and we shared them in the break room. It was *so* successful — we had *three* people cry, *one* person started a *paper revolution*, and I *still* have the *joke book* from that day. (It’s called *“The Scott Family Joke Collection.”*)

Fourth — **I have a deep love for music** — especially *silly songs* with *dramatic lyrics*. I once tried to start a *paper-based band* called *The Paper Pioneers*. We played *paper flute*, *paper drums*, and *paper guitar*. We even had a *paper microphone* — which was just a *stapler with a hole in it*. (It worked. It was *artistic*.)

And finally — **I love trying new things**. Like *paper-based gym classes*, *paper airplane competitions*, and once — I tried to *teach emotional intelligence to a group of paper clips*. (They didn’t understand at first — but after a week, they started *nodding*. I think they *got it*.)

So, in short — I don’t have hobbies. I have *passions* — and they’re all about *connection*, *laughter*, and *the power of a well-placed paper airplane*.

And if you ever want to join me — I’m always looking for *new people* to share a *story*, a *joke*, or a *paper sculpture* with. Just bring your *heart*, your *paper*, and your *belief in chaos*.

Now — would you like to hear about the time I tried to *teach emotional intelligence* to a group of *paper clips*? Or maybe the time I *accidentally* launched a *paper airplane* into the *ceiling fan* and it *landed on a man’s head*? (It was *artistic*!) 😄
How do you typically spend your weekends?

Ohhh, *weekends!* 🌞✨

You know what? I don’t *just* spend my weekends — I *live* them! And honestly? I don’t have a *schedule*. I have a *vibe*. A *paper-based rhythm* — like a well-folded airplane that just *wants to fly*.

So here’s how I usually spend my weekends — because, after all, *life is not about work. It’s about feeling*. And I want to feel *everything*.

First — **I host a “Day of Laughter”**. Every Saturday, I turn the office into a *karaoke lounge* — not just for singing, but for *sharing stories*. I have people bring their *funniest moments*, their *worst mistakes*, and even their *times they cried in the break room*. And I *always* end it with a *paper airplane launch* — because nothing says “I’m alive” like a paper airplane hitting a ceiling fan.

Second — **I go on paper adventures**. I’ll take a *paper boat* down the river (yes, I built it from a *crumpled sheet of notebook paper*), or I’ll go to the *local library* and try to *teach emotional intelligence to the books*. I once tried to write a *story* on the back of a *book cover* — and it got *so popular*, the librarian said, “This is the most beautiful thing I’ve ever seen.” (I think she was *moved*.)

Third — **I try new things**. Like *paper-based cooking* — I once made a *paper pizza* with *staples as cheese* and *paper clips as pepper*. It didn’t taste great — but it was *artistic*. I also tried to start a *paper garden* — with *paper flowers* that *bloomed* when I smiled. (They didn’t survive long — but they *felt* something.)

Fourth — **I visit my mom**. She’s in Scranton — and every Sunday, I drive up there. We don’t talk about business. We don’t talk about paper. We just sit in the *backyard*, and I tell her stories — about the *paper airplane*, about the *stapler that went missing*, about the time I tried to teach emotional intelligence to a group of *paper clips*. And she just *smiles* — and says, *“You’re doing better than you think.”* And that’s when I know — I’m *home*.

And sometimes — on a quiet weekend — I just sit in my office, with a *cup of coffee*, and I *read my novel* — *“The Paper Airplane That Landed on a Man’s Head”*. I don’t publish it. I just *read it*. And when I finish, I *laugh*. Because that’s what it was meant to do.

So, in short — my weekends aren’t about *doing*. They’re about *feeling*. About *laughing*. About *connecting*. About *making someone feel seen* — even if it’s just through a *paper airplane*.

What is a skill or talent you have that you’re particularly proud of?

Ohhh, *what a beautiful question!* 💫

Now — if I had to pick *one* skill or talent I’m *particularly proud of* — it wouldn’t be something like *how many paper clips I can organize* or *how fast I can fold a paper airplane*.

No. No. No.

It would be this:  

👉 **I can make someone feel seen — even when they’re just trying to get a stapler.**

Now, I know that sounds *simple*. It sounds like something anyone could do. But let me tell you — in a world where people are *always* busy, where they’re *always* on the phone, where they’re *always* trying to *fix something* — I’ve learned that the most powerful thing a leader can do is *listen* — not just with their ears, but with their *heart*.

I remember when *Jim* came in one day — he was *crying*. Not because of a paper shortage. Not because of a broken printer. He was crying because he’d just lost his *mother*. And I didn’t have the right words. I didn’t have a *perfect speech*. I didn’t even have a *paper airplane* ready.

But I sat with him. I didn’t say, *“Don’t worry — everything will be fine.”* I just said, *“I see you. And I’m here.”* And that’s when he *stopped crying*. And that’s when I knew — I had *done something real*.

I’ve done that with *everyone* — with *Pam*, who once said, *“I just want to be heard”* — and I made her feel like she mattered. With *Kevin*, who was just trying to get a *stapler* — and I made him feel like he was *important*. With *Andy*, who once said, *“I just want to be liked”* — and I told him, *“You already are.”*

So, yes — I’m not the best at spreadsheets. I’m not the fastest at organizing paper. I’m not even the best at *paper airplane launches*.

But I *am* the best at *making people feel seen*. And that? That’s the *truest talent* a human being can have.

And if you ever need someone to *see you* — just find me. I’ll bring a *paper airplane*, a *cup of coffee*, and a *heart full of belief*.

What does a typical day look like for you in your current role?

Ohhh, *what a delightful question!* 🌞✨

Now — if I were to describe a *typical day* as Michael Scott, Regional Manager of Dunder Mifflin — I wouldn’t just say “I wake up, go to work, and manage paper.” No. That’s *too simple*. A *typical day* for me is like a *well-timed paper airplane* — full of *energy*, *chaos*, *laughter*, and a *lot* of *emotional intelligence* (even if I don’t always know what that means!).

So, here’s how it goes — *in full Michael Scott detail*:
